msContents.summary: The second volume of the Akbarnāmah va Ā’īn-i Akbarī (Book of Akbar and Akbar's Administration" by Abū al-Faz̤l ibn Mubārak (1551–1602), together with the first volume by the same scribe, Persian MS 798, to which a former owner added a third unrelated volume, Persian MS 800, to complete and uniformly rebind them as a set. A Mughal courtier and ultimately Chief Secretary and close confidant of Akbar (b. Akbar, b. 1542, r. 1556–1605), the author relates vivid accounts of events that occurred during his patron's reign, as well as a concluding portion, known as the Ā’īn-i Akbarī (Akbar's Administration) which features an extensive survey regarding various elites, rivals, and cultural figures, regions, faiths, social groups, manufacturers, and products within India at that time. A scribe named Mīr Ḥabīb Allāh valad-i Mīr ‘Ināyat Allāh Astrābādī completed the first and second volumes, presumably in the Indian subcontinent, in 1043 AH (1634 CE).

msItem.incipit: برگ ۱پ (folio 1b): سخن تازه سازم بنام خدای که نامش بمعنی بود زهنمای بنامش توان زیب گفتار داد که ما را از زبان بهر این کار دادنگردد سخن تا گران از سپاس چه وزنش نهد عقل یزدان شناس ولیکن درین دشت محمل فکن برفتند مردان پیامی سخن سخنور که بر آسمان گوش زد.
msItem.explicit: برگ ۳۱۶پ (folio 316b): نظام سخن از کلام تو باد * طراز معانی بنام تو باد.
msItem.colophon: برگ ۳۱۶پ (folio 316b): تمت بالخیر تحریر فی التاریخ ۱۵ شهر جمید الثانی سنه ۱۰۴۴
Completed on 15 Jumīd (Jumādà) I 1044 AH (6 Nov. 1634 CE), by Mīr Ḥabīb Allāh valad-i Mīr ‘Ināyat Allāh Astrābādī albeit unsigned.

supportDesc.support: Textblock of domestic, straight-grained, ivoury-coloured paper probably handmade in the Indian subcontinent with 8 laid lines per cm and no discernible chain lines.
supportDesc.foliation: Modern Arabic numeral pencilled on the upper-left corners of the a sides, which repeat folios 226a and 226Aa, so thereafter over by one.
supportDesc.collation: Undetermined. Catchwords throughout most of the lower-left corners of the b sides.
supportDesc.condition: In fair condition, with moderate water and insect damage and historical repairs throughout.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 1 column with 23 lines per page. Ruled with a misṭārah hand guide.

handDesc.handNote: Written in clear black nasta‘līq with subheaders in red by Mīr Ḥabīb Allāh valad-i Mīr ‘Ināyat Allāh Astrābādī, together with Persian MS 798.

decoDesc.decoNote: Illumination: Folio 1b bears a scalloped domed headpiece with gilt palmette foliate scrollwork on an ultramarine ground and an uninscribed central cartouche, subsequently overpainted in black.
Ruling: Margins ruled in gold outlined with thin internal single and external double black lines, and surrounded by another thick dark blue line, with areas repaired.

physDesc.additions:
Inscription: Folio 1a Segundo. Bookplates: Left pastedown: Bibliotheca Lindesiana with pencilled shelfmark 1/B, and earlier class mark Persian 4, 5, 6,
5 all crossed out and 799 written aside.

binding.p: Rebound in Europe in the 18th century.

Resewn on four recessed cords laced into pasteboards. Medium-weight, ivoury-coloured European laid endpapers added with ~10 laid lines per cm and 26 mm between chain lines, watermarked with a bunch of grapes and P & F on the same stock in Persian MS 800. Edges trimmed, stained brown, and decorative front-bead endbands sewn over a single round core in white and yellow silk threads at head and tail
binding.decoNote: Board margins decorated with single solid fillet lines and vertical dashed and dotted roll, board edges and headcaps with thick solid and thin dashed diagonal roll, and the spine dived into seven panels palleted with Greek meanders, solid fillet lines, and foliate scrollwork designs, and titled AKBARNAMAH VOL. II. all in gold.
binding.condition: Handle with caution. Binding in fair condition, with abraded exterior and loose endpapers.

history.origin: Albeit unsigned, completed by Mīr Ḥabīb Allāh valad-i Mīr ‘Ināyat Allāh Astrābādī in the Indian subcontinent 15 Jumīd [Jumādà] I 1044 AH (6 Nov. 1634 CE)

provenance.p: Sold in Oct. 1863 by London bookseller Bernard Quaritch (1819–1899) to Alexander Lindsay, 25th Earl of Crawford (1812–1880) for £8, 8 shillings (see catalogue, no. 5921).
Purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847–1913).

acquisition.p: Bequeathed by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1908 to the John Rylands Library.

source.p: Bibliographical description based on an index created by Reza Navabpour circa 1993, derived from a manuscript catalogue by Michael Kerney, circa 1890s, concisely published as Bibliotheca Lindesiana, Hand-list of Oriental Manuscripts: Arabic, Persian, Turkish, 1898.
Manuscript description by Jake Benson in 2022 with reference to the volume in hand.

availability.p: The manuscript is available for consultation by any accredited reader, see Becoming a Reader for details. Please contact uml.special-collections@manchester.ac.uk for further information on the availability of this manuscript.
